name: Birds of North America Quiz | Wild Birds | 15 Questions

questions.text: This mostly-white owl is sometimes called the 'monkey-faced owl'. Farmers put up nest boxes for it because it can consume many rodents each night.
questions.explanation:
Barn owl.

	The barn owl is one of the most widespread species of bird in the world, found on all continents except Antarctica.

questions.text: This rare bird, found only in some remote areas along the Mexican border, is the only remaining member of the parrot family native to the United States.
questions.explanation:
Thick-billed parrot.

	The Carolina parakeet is extinct. The monk parakeet and red-headed Amazon have been released or escaped from captivity in several areas of the U.S.

questions.text: This ground-dwelling desert native, famous for snake killing and cartoon appearances, is really a member of the cuckoo family.
questions.explanation:
Roadrunner.

	Unlike many cuckoos, roadrunners do care for their own young.

questions.text: This vulture, reintroduced into the wild in several areas in the West, has the largest wingspan of any North American land bird.
questions.explanation:
California condor.

	This huge vulture was nearly wiped out by humans' guns, traps and poisons.

questions.text: This black, white and red bird stores its food in holes that it drills into tree trunks. Its 'Ja-cob, ja-cob' call is one of the most familiar sounds in California's oak woodlands.
questions.explanation:
Acorn woodpecker.

	Sometimes hundreds of acorns will be stored in one tree trunk. Occasionally they use house sidings for the same purpose- filling the gaps between the house walls with thousands of acorns!

questions.text: This family of diminutive birds can fly backwards and has members bold enough to chase hawks and eagles away from their nests.
questions.explanation:
Hummingbirds.

	Hummingbirds expend tremendous amounts of energy every day.

questions.text: These birds are widely regarded by avian researchers as being some of the most intelligent animals. They can count and can solve surprisingly complex problems. They fly acrobatics and slide down snow-covered hills for fun. They can also be taught to talk.
questions.explanation:
Ravens.

	All of the corvids are bright, but ravens are perhaps the brightest.

questions.text: This bird was sometimes called 'fool hen' by explorers, because it would not fly or run away from hunters but would stand still and allow itself to be killed.
questions.explanation:
Ptarmigan.

	The birds are found in Northern areas. Their plumage is brown in summer and white in winter, thus their defense is camouflage instead of flight.

questions.text: Males of this common songbird will attack small red objects and even their own reflections in a mirror.
questions.explanation:
Robin.

	They react to the red color as representing an intruding male.

questions.text: This odd marsh bird makes a sound like a rusty old water pump. Rarely seen, it blends into the brown marsh grasses almost perfectly, even stretching its head and bill straight up into the air to resemble grass stems.
questions.explanation:
Bittern.

	Bitterns have long, sharp bills that can easily poke out an eye.

questions.text: This gigantic white bird with a red head patch is one of the rarest species in the United States. It nests in Canada and winters in Texas. Researchers remove the first eggs laid from the Canadian nests to be raised by a related species of bird. The parents then will lay and raise a second clutch.
questions.explanation:
Whooping crane.

	The much more numerous sandhill cranes are the foster parents.

questions.text: These insect-eating birds are among the world's best fliers. They build nests of mud. They are perhaps most famous for the legend of their annual return to the mission of San Juan Capistrano in California.
questions.explanation:
Cliff swallows.

	Very few swallows return to Capistrano any more.

questions.text: Members of this family of birds are unusual because they can drink without raising their heads. They also produce a special food for their nestlings in their stomachs and regurgitate this food.
questions.explanation:
Pigeons and doves.

	Other birds have to raise their heads and let the water trickle down their throats. The nestling food is called 'pigeon milk'.

questions.text: This bird is famous for its imitative powers, copying such diverse sounds as lawnmowers, hawks, and cats. An excellent songster, it often sings at night.
questions.explanation:
Mockingbird.

	Mockingbirds are rarely seen at feeders because they eat insects and fruit rather than seeds.

questions.text: This tiny mountain songbird dives into swiftly-running streams to procure its food.
questions.explanation:
Ouzel.

	It's also known as a dipper.
